4.5                     Traffic
                                                The existing transportation system in the Study A rea w as evaluated to determine
                                                the transportation impacts that w ould be associated w ith the Red Line/ Blue Line
                                                Project. A n effective evaluation of existing conditions throughout the Study A rea
                                                requires an understanding of current traffic volumes, pedestrian and bicycle
                                                demands, operations, safety and geometric conditions. The existing conditions
                                                evaluation focuses on morning and evening peak hour traffic, pedestrian and
                                                bicycle volumes; recent crash history along the Study A rea corridor; traffic
                                                operations; and pedestrian operations. Bicycle operations are qualitatively
                                                discussed. A parking evaluation w as performed to support a future conditions
                                                assessment of potential parking impacts associated w ith construction of the Red
                                                Line/ Blue Line Project. A n inventory of the roadw ay and intersection geometry
                                                used in support of the existing conditions analysis is provided in the A ppendix.

                                                The follow ing sections describe the data collected and analyses conducted for the
                                                existing conditions assessment.



4.5.1                   Study Area
                                                A s required by the Secretary's Certificate on the Expanded Environmental
                                                N otification Form (EEN F), a meeting w as convened betw een representatives of the
                                                Department of Conservation and Recreation (DCR), the M assachusetts H ighw ay
                                                Department (M assH ighw ay), and the City of Boston Transportation Department
                                                (BTD) to discuss Study A rea roadw ays and intersections. A t that meeting, ten
                                                intersections w ere selected for the existing conditions evaluation (see Figure 4.5.1):

                                                        Cambridge Street at:
                                                         Charles Circle - Longfellow Bridge outbound/ Storrow Drive w estbound
                                                           off-ramp (unsignalized w ith flashing red and yellow signals);
                                                         Charles Circle - Charles Street/ Storrow Drive eastbound
                                                           off-ramp/ Longfellow Bridge inbound (signalized);
                                                         Charles Circle - Charles Street northbound/ Storrow Drive w estbound
                                                           on-ramp (signalized);
                                                         N orth Grove Street/ Grove Street (signalized);
                                                         N orth A nderson Street/ A nderson Street (unsignalized);
                                                         Blossom Street/ Garden Street (signalized);
                                                         Joy Street (signalized w ith fire pre-emption);
                                                         Staniford Street/ Temple Street (signalized);
                                                         N ew Chardon Street/ Bow doin Street (signalized); and
                                                         N ew Sudbury Street/ Somerset Street (signalized).

                                                Once a preferred alternative and method of construction is identified, additional
                                                data collection may be required. These data w ould be discussed, as applicable, in
                                                Chapter 5, Environmental Consequences and in the Environmental Consequences
                                                Technical Report for traffic.


4.5.2                   Traffic Volumes
                                                To estimate the baseline traffic condition at the Study A rea intersections, a review of
                                                the existing condition traffic volumes w as completed. Daily morning and evening
                                                peak hour traffic volume data w ithin the Study A rea w ere collected on
                                                A pril 29, 2009. These volumes are presented in Figure 4.5-2. Daily traffic volume
                                                data w ere collected along the follow ing roadw ays for a 24-hour period:

                                                        Cambridge Street, over Storrow Drive (Longfellow Bridge);
                                                        Cambridge Street, betw een Joy Street and Blossom Street;
                                                        Cambridge Street, east of Somerset Street;
                                                        Charles Street, north of Cambridge Street;
                                                        Storrow Drive eastbound off-ramp to Charles Circle;
                                                        Storrow Drive w estbound on-ramp from Charles Circle;
                                                        Storrow Drive w estbound off-ramp to Charles Circlet;
                                                        Grove Street, south of Cambridge Street;
                                                        Joy Street, south of Cambridge Street;
                                                        Staniford Street, north of Cambridge Street;
                                                        Temple Street, south of Cambridge Street;
                                                        N ew Chardon Street, north of Cambridge Street;
                                                        Bow doin Street, south of Cambridge Street;
                                                        N ew Sudbury Street, north of Cambridge Street; and
                                                        Somerset Street, south of Cambridge Street.

                                                These counts w ill be used to assist in determining the construction related impacts
                                                associated w ith the project. Observed traffic volumes are summarized in Table 4.5-1.
                                                The role of Cambridge Street as a major commuter route is demonstrated by the
                                                majority of the traffic traveling eastbound tow ards Government Center during the
                                                morning peak hour, and the majority of the traffic traveling w estbound, aw ay from
                                                Government Center during the evening peak hour. The majority of the traffic on the
                                                Longfellow Bridge travels w estbound into Cambridge during the morning peak
                                                hour and eastbound tow ard Boston during the evening peak hour. The difference in
                                                peak travel direction betw een the Longfellow Bridge and Cambridge Street may
                                                reflect the role of Storrow Drive as a major commuter route for people traveling to
                                                and from the City of Cambridge. The Storrow Drive on-ramp and Charles Street
                                                northbound have their highest traffic volume during the evening peak hour as
                                                commuters leave Boston and Cambridge w hile the Storrow Drive eastbound and
                                                w estbound off-ramps have their highest volumes during the morning peak hour as
                                                commuters enter the area.

4.5.3                   Intersection Safety
                                                A safety assessment w as conducted for Study A rea intersections using
                                                M assH ighw ay crash records for 2005 through 2007 (the most recent three years for
                                                w hich data are currently available). These data include all reported crashes at Study
                                                A rea intersections w ith property damage greater than $1,000 or crashes that
                                                involved personal injuries or fatalities.

                                                A s noted in Section 4.5.1, Charles Circle includes three intersections. The
                                                organization of the crash data makes it difficult to locate exactly w here crashes
                                                occur w ithin Charles Circle; therefore, the crashes are presented as a single location
                                                for all of Charles Circle. Table 4.5-2 presents the intersection safety analysis for the
                                                Study A rea intersections. Six Study A rea intersections experience, on average, five
                                                or few er crashes per year. This includes Cambridge Street at Joy Street and
                                                Cambridge Street at A nderson Street w here no crashes w ere reported over the
                                                three-year period studied.

                                                Charles Circle and the intersection of Cambridge Street at N ew Chardon
                                                Street/ Bow doin Street are the only locations that experience an average greater than
                                                five crashes per year. The N ew Chardon Street/ Bow doin Street intersection had 19
                                                reported crashes over the three years period. Charles Circle experienced 55 crashes,
                                                or an average of more than 18 per year. This is likely a result of the heavy traffic
                                                volume that Charles Circle processes and the geometry of the Circle, w hich can be
                                                confusing to drivers not familiar w ith the area.

                                     Red Line/Blue Line Connector                               Affected Environment
                                     Project


 Table 4.5-2 Crash Data Analysis

                                                                                                                                                      Cambridge Street at

                                    Red Line/Blue Line Connector                                      Affected Environment
                                    Project


                                                A s part of the safety assessment, crash rates w ere calculated for all Study A rea
                                                intersections. A crash rate is the representative number of crashes that occur at a
                                                particular intersection for every 1,000,000 vehicles that enter that intersection. For
                                                example, a crash rate of 1.0 indicates that one crash occurs at an intersection for
                                                every 1,000,000 vehicles that enter it. The calculated crash rates w ere compared to
                                                the current statew ide average crash rates (0.87 for signalized intersections and
                                                0.66 for unsignalized intersections) and M assH ighw ay District 4 average crash rates
                                                (0.88 for signalized intersections and 0.63 for unsignalized intersections) to
                                                determine w hether intersections in the Study A rea experience greater than average
                                                crash occurrences. Only Charles Circle exceeds the M assH ighw ay statew ide and
                                                District average crash rates. A s noted above, the Charles Circle crash rate combines
                                                the three intersections that form Charles Circle. Since it is not possible to
                                                disaggregate the data, it cannot be determined w hether any specific location w ithin
                                                Charles Circle has a disproportionately high number of crashes.

                                                The safety assessment also included a review of the statew ide H igh Crash Location
                                                    1
                                                list . This list includes the top 1,000 crash locations w ithin the Commonw ealth. One
                                                of the Study A rea intersections (Embankment Road and Charles Circle) appears on
                                                the list in the top 100, ranking at 43. Since the available data does not distinguish
                                                specific locations w ithin Charles Circle, no direct correlation betw een the H igh
                                                Crash Location and high crash rate can be made. H ow ever, it should be noted that
                                                although Charles Circle exceed the statew ide average crash rate, zero fatalities w ere
                                                reported at the intersections w ithin Charles Circle during the three year period
                                                analyzed. The 2005 H igh Crash Location list is based on crash statistics from 1999 to
                                                2001. A ny safety modifications to the intersections made since 2001 are not reflected
                                                in the rankings available.



4.5.4                   Intersection Geometrics and Traffic Control
                                                Existing intersection geometries w ere collected at the Study A rea intersections in
                                                June 2009. The majority (eight of 10) of the Study A rea intersections are under traffic
                                                signal control. Traffic signal timing and phasing plans w ere obtained from the
                                                traffic signal controllers at each signalized intersection and confirmed w ith BTD.
                                                Detailed geometrics and traffic signal information is provided in the A ppendix.



        4.5.4.1 Traffic Operations Analysis

                                                Intersection capacity analyses w ere conducted for the Study A rea intersections
                                                based on the existing traffic volumes and traffic control. Capacity analyses provide
                                                an indication of how w ell the intersections accommodate the traffic demands placed
                                                upon them. Intersection operating conditions are classified by calculated level of


                                                
                                                1     Top 1,000 High Crash Location Report (1999-2001), MassHighway 2005




Affected Environment                                                                    4-6                 Prepared by Vanasse Hangen Brustlin, Inc. ­ 09/18/09
B:\tech\Traffic\Affected Environment\AE_Section4.5-Traffic.docx
                                    Red Line/Blue Line Connector                                       Affected Environment
                                    Project


                                                service (LOS) as described below . SYNCHRO Version 7.0, an intersection analysis
                                                computer softw are w as used to model traffic conditions at the Study A rea
                                                intersections. The evaluation criteria used to analyze the Study A rea intersections
                                                                                                 2
                                                are based on the 2000 Highway Capacity M anual.

                                                Level of service is the term used to denote the different operating conditions that
                                                occur at a given intersection under various traffic conditions. It is a qualitative
                                                measure of the effect of a number of factors including roadw ay geometrics, speed,
                                                travel delay, freedom to maneuver, and safety. Level of service provides an index to
                                                the operational qualities of an intersection. Level of service designations range from
                                                A to F, w ith LOS A representing the optimal operating conditions w ith little or no
                                                delay and LOS F representing the w orst operating conditions w ith high congestion
                                                and long delays. LOS D or better is generally considered an acceptable operating
                                                condition. In urban areas how ever, LOS E may sometimes be considered an
                                                acceptable condition. Thresholds for vehicular levels of service are show n in
                                                Table 4.5-3.


                                                Table 4.5-3            Vehicular Level of Service Thresholds
                                                                                                           Average Delay (seconds)
                                                            Level of Service            Signalized Intersection             Unsignalized Intersection
                                                                   A                             <10                               <10
                                                                   B                             > 10 to 20                        > 10 to 15
                                                                   C                             > 20 to 35                        > 15 to 25
                                                                   D                             > 35 to 55                        > 25 to 35
                                                                   E                             > 55 to 80                        > 35 to 50
                                                                   F                             > 80                              > 50
                                                Source: 2000 H ighw ay Capacity Manual


                                                Level of service designations are reported differently for signalized and
                                                unsignalized intersections. For signalized intersections, the analysis considers the
                                                operation of each lane group entering the intersection and the level of service
                                                designation represents overall conditions at the intersection. For unsignalized
                                                intersections, the analysis assumes that traffic on the main street is not affected by
                                                traffic on the minor side streets. The level of service in this case is determined
                                                separately for left-turns from the main street and all movements from the minor
                                                street. The unsignalized intersection level of service presented is for the most critical
                                                movement, often the left-turns out of the side street. The results of the existing
                                                conditions traffic operations analysis for signalized intersections are presented in
                                                Tables 4.5-4.




                                                
                                                2     2000 Highway Capacity Manual, Special Report 209, Transportation Research Board, Washington D.C., 2000

    Cambridge Street and Staniford Street/Temple Street                                  0.82           37            D        0.70           35           C

                                                A s show n in Table 4.5-4, the follow ing three signalized intersections currently
                                                operate at an unacceptable LOS E or LOS F during one or both peak hours:

                                                        Charles Circle -- Charles Street/ Storrow Drive eastbound off-ramp;
                                                        Cambridge Street and N ew Chardon Street/ Bow doin Street; and
                                                        Cambridge Street and N ew Sudbury Street/ Somerset Street.

                                                The results of the existing conditions traffic operations analysis for unsignalized
                                                intersections are presented in Table 4.5-5. It should be noted that Cambridge Street
                                                at the Storrow Drive w estbound off-ramp operates as a stop-controlled intersection
                                                (flashing traffic signal) and each approach carries one-w ay traffic only. The Storrow
                                                Drive w estbound off-ramp traffic is STOP controlled w ith a flashing red indication
                                                and Cambridge Street w estbound is given a flashing yellow indication. Both Charles
                                                Circle at Cambridge Street/ Storrow Drive w estbound off-ramp and Cambridge
                                                Street at N orth A nderson Street/ A nderson Street currently operate at an
                                                unacceptable LOS F during one of the peak hours.

4.5.5                   Emergency Vehicles and Truck Access
                                                M ajor roadw ay access for emergency vehicles and heavy trucks traveling to, from
                                                and through the Study A rea w ere identified in order to determine the nature and
                                                magnitude of potential construction impacts. The emergency vehicles parking areas
                                                and the loading docks for the buildings w ithin the Study A rea are show n in
                                                Figure 4.5-3. There are five emergency vehicle areas and seven loading docks in the
                                                immediate vicinity of Cambridge Street. Emergency vehicle areas are located at:

                                                        M assachusetts General H ospital;
                                                        M assachusetts Eye and Eye Infirmary;
                                                        Shriners Burns Institute;
                                                        Boston Fire Station; and
                                                        Boston Police Station (District 1).

                                                Truck loading docks are located at:

                                                        The Liberty H otel;
                                                        M assachusetts General H ospital (multiple locations);
                                                        M assachusetts Eye and Ear Infirmary;
                                                        Shriners Burns Institute;
                                                        Charles River Plaza/ Whole Foods Supermarket;
                                                        State Service Center; and
                                                        M cCormick State Office Building.

                                                M ajor roadw ays for emergency vehicle access to and from the Study A rea include
                                                Interstate 93/ Route 1/ Route 3, Route 28, Longfellow Bridge, and Storrow Drive.
                                                With the exception of Storrow Drive, these roadw ays also provide access for trucks.
                                                Storrow Drive is designated as a parkw ay by DCR and buses and trucks are
                                                prohibited. On the local roadw ay system, emergency vehicles and trucks can access
                                                any roads w ithin the Study A rea except Bow doin Street or H ancock Street, w here
                                                trucks over 2.5 tons and buses are prohibited. Trucks are also prohibited from Cedar
                                                                                                        3
                                                Street and South Russell Street w ithin the Study A rea. A ll state numbered routes,
                                                including those w ithin the City of Boston, are designated truck routes, w ith the
                                                exception of any portions that are ow ned by DCR.



        4.5.5.1 Interstate 93/Route 1/Route 3

                                                Traveling northbound, emergency vehicles and trucks can access the Study A rea via
                                                I-93 (Exit 23) and N orth Street w hich connects w ith Congress Street. Congress Street
                                                provides access to Cambridge Street via N ew Chardon Street and Staniford Street.


                                                
                                                3
                                                 City of Cambridge Truck Routes. http://www.cambridgema.gov/CityOfCambridge_Content/documents/trucks-day.pdf

                                                Egress from the Study A rea to I-93/ Route 1/ Route 3 northbound is generally via
                                                Charles Street to Leverett Circle or via N ew Sudbury Street.

                                                Traveling southbound, emergency vehicles and trucks can access the Study A rea via
                                                Leverett Circle and Embankment Road (Storrow Drive) to Charles Circle or via I-93
                                                (Exit 24 A -B) and N ew Chardon Street. Egress from the Study A rea to I-93
                                                southbound is generally via Staniford Street, M errimack Street and N ew Chardon
                                                Street, w hich connects directly to I-93/ Route 1/ Route 3 southbound.



        4.5.5.2 Route 28/Storrow Drive

                                                Traveling Route 28 northbound or Storrow Drive eastbound, emergency vehicles
                                                can access the Study A rea via Charles Circle. Charles Street northbound or Blossom
                                                Street can be used by trucks and emergency vehicles to egress from the Study A rea
                                                to the north through Leverett Circle. A lternate egress is provided via Staniford
                                                Street, w hich connects to Route 28 (M onsignor O`Brien H ighw ay) via N ashua Street
                                                and the Charles River Dam Bridge.

                                                Traveling Route 28 southbound, access to the Study A rea is provided via
                                                                                                      4
                                                Embankment Road (Storrow Drive) to Charles Circle . Egress from the Study A rea
                                                to the w est is provided by Storrow Drive at Charles Circle and via Beacon Street.



        4.5.5.3 Longfellow Bridge (Route 3)

                                                Emergency vehicles and trucks use the Longfellow Bridge for access betw een
                                                Boston and Cambridge.



        4.5.5.4 Partners HealthCare Shuttle Services
                                                In addition to emergency vehicles and trucks, Partners H ealthCare provides shuttle
                                                services for the convenience of M assachusetts General H ospital (M GH ) employees,
                                                patients and visitors. The follow ing shuttle routes operate on a fixed schedule
                                                M onday through Friday (except holidays). Service times and headw ays vary by
                                                route:

                                                        M GH Parking Lots;
                                                        M GH M ain Campus, N orth Station, One Constitution Road, Charlestow n N avy
                                                        Yard (Saturday and Sunday services are also provided for this route);
                                                        M GH M ain Campus, Partners H ealthCare (Prudential Center) and Brigham and
                                                        Women's H ospital;


                                                
                                                4
                                                    Due to bus and truck restrictions on Storrow Drive, all trucks must exit at Charles Circle exit.

                                                        M GH to Charlestow n (Bunker H ill H ealth Center) and N orth End H ealth

                                                The entire route for the Campus Loop shuttle runs w ithin the Study A rea. The
                                                Campus Loop travels along Charles Street, Blossom Street, William Cardinal
                                                O'Connell Way, Staniford Street, Cambridge Street, Parkman Street, and Fruit
                                                Street. Figure 4.5-3 show s the route of the Campus Loop shuttle.



4.5.6                   Pedestrians and Bicycles
                                                A s part of the data collection, pedestrian volumes and bicycle turning movements
                                                w ere observed at each of the Study A rea intersections during the w eekday morning
                                                and evening peak hours. Figure 4.5-4 presents the morning and evening peak hour
                                                pedestrian and bicycle volumes. A pproximately 200 to 700 pedestrians w ere noted
                                                along Cambridge Street during each peak hour. The number of pedestrians
                                                traveling to and from the Charles/ M GH M BTA station w as observed to be 1,574
                                                during the morning peak hour and 1,883 during the evening peak hour.



        4.5.6.1 Pedestrian Operations

                                                Crossw alk analyses w ere conducted at all Study A rea intersections. Pedestrian
                                                Level of Service (PLOS) provides an index to quantify pedestrian delay similar to
                                                that of vehicles, w ith PLOS A representing excellent pedestrian operations and
                                                PLOS F representing an unacceptable delay for pedestrians w aiting to cross the
                                                roadw ay. Thresholds for PLOS are noted in Table 4.5-6.


                                                Table 4.5-6           Pedestrian Level of Service Thresholds
                                                      Pedestrian                                   Average Delay per Pedestrian (seconds)
                                                      Level of Service                 Signalized Intersection           Likelihood of Compliance
                                                                  A                             <10                                 Very High
                                                                  B                             > 10 to 20                          High
                                                                  C                             > 20 to 30                          High
                                                                  D                             > 30 to 40                          Low
                                                                  E                             > 40 to 60                          Moderate
                                                                  F                             > 60                                High
                                                Source: 2000 Highway Capacity Manual




Affected Environment                                                                     4-11                Prepared by Vanasse Hangen Brustlin, Inc. ­ 09/18/09
B:\tech\Traffic\Affected Environment\AE_Section4.5-Traffic.docx
                                 Red Line/Blue Line Connector                            Affected Environment
                                 Project


                                                                 This Page Intentionally Left Blank.




Affected Environment                                                                          Prepared by Vanasse Hangen Brustlin, Inc. ­ 09/18/09
\\Mabos\projects\10803.00\tech\Traffic\Appendix\RBLC_APPX.docx
                                    Red Line/Blue Line Connector                         Affected Environment
                                    Project


                                                Pedestrian delay w as calculated using the 2000 Highway Capacity M anual equation
                                                18-5 for signalized intersections. A t signalized intersections, the PLOS measured for
                                                pedestrian crossings is not a function of the capacity of the crossing but a function of
                                                the green time allotted for pedestrians to cross. A ccording to the Highway Capacity
                                                M anual , pedestrians experiencing more than a 30-second delay become more
                                                impatient and more noncompliant w ith the signal indications. H ow ever, at
                                                intersections w ith high conflicting vehicle volumes, w hich is the prevailing
                                                condition w ithin the Study A rea, pedestrians have no choice but to w ait for the w alk
                                                signal and their disregard of the signal indication is reduced.

                                                Based on the length of the individual crossw alks and a 3.5 foot per second w alking
                                                speed, the crossing time at each crossw alk w as calculated. In conformance w ith
                                                signal design guidelines, this crossing time represents the flashing " Don't Walk"
                                                phase of the traffic signal cycle. For locations w ith concurrent pedestrian phasing,
                                                the flashing " Don't Walk" time (minus four seconds per the H CM ) w as subtracted
                                                from the total red-time for the approach, deriving an effective w alk (green time) for
                                                pedestrians. Where an exclusive pedestrian phase is provided, it forms the basis for
                                                the PLOS analysis.

                                                Table 4.5-7 presents the PLOS analysis. Ten crossw alks at five signalized
                                                intersections operate at PLOS E or PLOS F during at least one peak hour. This poor
                                                PLOS is the result of the long traffic signal cycle lengths needed to process vehicular
                                                traffic and a relatively short pedestrian crossing phase.

                                                                                    Average Ped                  Average Ped
  Intersection                                                       Crosswalk       Delay (sec)     PLOS         Delay (sec)        PLOS
  Cambridge Street at                                                East                19            B               8               A
  Storrow Drive Westbound On Ramp
  Cambridge Street at Charles Street/                                South               33             D              25               C
  Storrow Drive Eastbound Off-Ramp and                               West (North)        14             B              21               C
  Longfellow Bridge Inbound                                          West (South)        31             D              24               C
                                                                     East (North)        13             B              19               B
                                                                     East (South)        32             D              25               C
  Cambridge Street at                                                North               11             B              4                A
  North Grove Street/ Grove Street                                   South               27             C              32               D
                                                                     East                36             D              41               E
                                                                     West                38             D              43               E
  Cambridge Street at                                                North               21             C              21               C
  Blossom Street/ Garden Street                                      South               34             D              36               D
                                                                     East                38             D              43               E

                                                The largest volume of bicycles w as observed along Cambridge Street. Observed
                                                bicycle volumes along Cambridge Street varied betw een 30 to 100 bicycles traveling
                                                eastbound during the morning peak hour and betw een 40 to 95 bicycles traveling
                                                w estbound during the evening peak hour along Cambridge Street.

                                                A safety assessment w as also conducted for the Study A rea intersections for
                                                pedestrians and bicycle safety. There w ere no reported crashes involving
                                                pedestrians or bicycles during the three-year period analyzed.

4.5.7                   Parking
                                                The Secretary's Certificate on the EN F required collection of parking supply and
                                                occupancy data w ithin 500 feet of the proposed alignment. The Study A rea
                                                inventory of on-street parking supply and parking regulations w as completed on
                                                A ugust 12, 2009. This inventory w ill help to determine the projects' potential impact
                                                to parking w ithin the Study A rea, particularly as it relates to construction. Figure
                                                4.5-5 show s the available parking supply and commercial loading zones in the
                                                Study A rea.



        4.5.7.1 Parking Regulations

                                                A s part of the existing conditions evaluation, parking regulations w ithin the Study
                                                A rea w ere documented. Table 4.5-8 summarizes the complete parking inventory
                                                along Cambridge Street and Table 4.5-9 summarizes the parking inventory along
                                                the minor streets, stretching 500 feet from Cambridge Street on either side of the
                                                roadw ay.

                                                Parking accumulation counts w ere taken at noon and 7:30 PM on A ugust 12, 2009.
                                                On Cambridge Street only one unoccupied space w as observed during the midday
                                                count. Fourteen spaces w ere unoccupied during the evening count. Suring the
                                                midday, there w ere many more unoccupied spaces on the intersecting streets that
                                                allow residential permit parking only. Table 4.5-10 and Table 4.5-11 summarize the
                                                parking utilization along Study A rea roadw ays.

 Affected Environment                                                                  4-18                 Prepared by Vanasse Hangen Brustlin, Inc. ­ 09/18/09
 B:\tech\Traffic\Affected Environment\AE_Section4.5-Traffic.docx
                                    Red Line/Blue Line Connector                             Affected Environment
                                    Project


Summary
                                                The existing conditions assessment for the Study A rea evaluated traffic, pedestrian
                                                and bicycle operations and safety statistics at 10 intersections along Cambridge
                                                Street. A comprehensive parking supply and regulation inventory w as also
                                                completed along Cambridge Street and intersecting streets. The results of the
                                                existing conditions assessment reveal the follow ing:

                                                        Charles Circle is currently ranked 43 on the M assH ighw ay Top 1,000 H igh
                                                        Crash Location list and exceeds the District 4 and Statew ide average crash rates.
                                                        Four signalized intersections and tw o unsignalized intersection currently
                                                        operate at unacceptable levels of service during at least one peak hour.
                                                        Pedestrians currently experience high delay at five of the signalized
                                                        intersections w ithin the Study A rea.
                                                        H eavy bicycle volumes w ere observed on Cambridge Street.
                                                        During field observations, it w as observed that resident parking spaces and
                                                        metered parking spaces are fully occupied during the midday and mostly
                                                        occupied in the evening.
